titleStmt.title: A thakns-giving [sic] for the recovery of Philip, Earl of Pembroke and Montgomery. Who being lately admitted into the supreame authority of the nation a Knight for Berkshire; was unfortunately jeared into a pestilent-feaver, which after turn'd to the fowl disease, but by the skill of a state-emperick and Mrs. May his nurse is happily recovered: and desires a thanksgiving for the same, from the supreame authority, and all other well-affected to the nation. Taken verbatim from his own mouth, by Michael Oldsworth.

A thakns-giving [sic] for the recovery of Philip, Earl of Pembroke and Montgomery. Who being lately admitted into the supreame authority of the nation a Knight for Berkshire; was unfortunately jeared into a pestilent-feaver, which after turn'd to the fowl disease, but by the skill of a state-emperick and Mrs. May his nurse is happily recovered: and desires a thanksgiving for the same, from the supreame authority, and all other well-affected to the nation. Taken verbatim from his own mouth, by Michael Oldsworth.
titleStmt.author: Oldisworth, Michael, 1591-1654?

publicationStmt.date: Printed in the happy yeer of the Lords liberty. 1649.

notesStmt.note: A satire on Pembroke, Oldisworth, and Mrs. May, Pembroke's mistress.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.
